subtitle: Let's go ahead and explore the different
ways that you can create arcs.
By definition, an arc is a segment of a
circle. So we have three different ways
of doing that. The easiest one is right
here, it's called Arc 3 points, and the
shortcut is A3.
So as the name suggests, all we need to
do is click three points, one, two and
three, and that's it.
I'll draw another arc over here.
One, two, three.
Note that each one of those points that I
clicked is on the arc itself.
Because these are segments of circles,
the arcs have center points that you can
snap to. So, for example, let's say I
want to draw a line from the center of
one arc to the center of the other.
I'll type LI for line.
And then I'll go in to reference mode,
and as this icon indicates, the center
point is marked, so I should be able to
draw a line from the center of this arc
to the center of this arc.
But the issue is trying to find it.
So if I just come over here and move
around a little bit in this area.
Somewhere in here, I'm going to find the
center of this arc.
I think it's right in this area right
there. There you go, it can be a little
tricky, but now I've drawn a line between
the center points of each one of those
arcs and arcs also have the north, south,
east and west reference points.
So there's the north point there on that
arc, and here's the east point on that
arc. Those are reference points that
exist on the arcs.
So that's pretty much all you need to
know about this particular tool.
Let's go back up and let's try this one
here, which is a little bit more
complicated, but it gives you a lot more
control over the way that the arc is
formed. I'm just going to pan over here
to give myself some blank area to draw.
OK, so let's try this command, it's
called Arc Radius and the keyboard
shortcut is AR.
And to create an arc like this, you have
to click four points.
The first point that you click is the
center, and then the next point
determines the radius of the arc.
And then you have this situation where as
you move the cursor, you can see that we
have this arc here.
And up on the options bar, you can choose
the direction. So that's the way that the
arc will be formed. So I've set it to
clockwise mode and now I'm going to click
my third point, which will determine the
start point of the arc.
And then the fourth point will determine
where that arc ends.
And so this gives you much more control
over the way that the arc is formed
because you're specifying all of these
points. Once again, it's the center, the
radius, the start and the end.
So if we want to be more constrained,
let's say we want to make an arc that
runs for exactly 90 degrees.
We can do that using ortho.
So, for example, I'll start drawing my
arc and I'll turn on ortho over here.
And I'll click the radius and then the
start. And then the end.
This is great for something like a door
swing. So I think this tool was initially
developed for that purpose, but we can
use it just to create arcs at specific
angles. If you want more granularity than
ortho affords, you can turn off ortho and
instead use "restrict angular length."
And then you can restrict either the
angle or the length or both.
Let's just try it with the angle of 15
degrees at first. So what I'm going to do
is click a point to start drawing.
Click a second point to specify the
radius and you'll see how the cursor
jumps in 15 degree increments.
So I could start it, let's say here at
the 45 degree angle mark, and I could
come down here and have it terminate
right there. And if I wanted the arc
radius to be a set value, I could turn on
distance. And then when I draw in my arc,
it jumps in these discrete increments of
five units. And I can go ahead and draw
in that arc. Having even more control
over in terms of the radius and the angle
that it's created. OK, so the last way of
creating an arc is this one here and this
is the Arc Tangent method and the
shortcut is AT.
And this will work with arcs or lines.
So let me just go ahead and draw the line
first. I'll type LI and I'll go ahead and
draw in some line here.
All right. Now, let's say I want to
create an arc that's tangent to that
line. I would use arc tangent.
And then click on the line and you can

is tangent to that line.
Depending on where I move the cursor, I

You can also change the radius up here.
Let's say I want that to be 10.
I'll just change that number and I'm

Let's say I want it to be only 3.
That arc is even tighter.

here. It's going to be making a new arc.
That's tangent to that one.
And of course, I can change the radius.
Let's say it's 10 now.
In this way, you can create a connected

The three different methods of creating
